text: Thursday's election was devastating for
the Labour Party and for every labor
supporter it's the result everyone
always fears
I think there's absolutely no point in
blaming the electorate any suggestion
that they didn't quote-unquote get it is
wrong they didn't want what was being
offered I think that both in 2010 and in
Gordon and then aired allowed themselves
to be portrayed as moving backwards from
the principles of aspiration and
inclusion that are at the absolute of
heart of any successful progressive
political project the answer is not to
go back to 1997 it's to build on the
achievements and remedy the weaknesses
but never to end up in a position where
the electoral thing that you're going
backwards rather than addressing the
issues of the future
you think Labour's lost the middle class
that it should return to a more Blair
right agenda I think that the
fundamental principles of an
aspirational and inclusive politics are
about middle class working class and
upper class and it's very very important
in a modern society which does have deep
inequalities but whose structure is very
much changed that we set out not to win
arguments about how you have a dynamic
economy how you achieve social reform
how you modernize posit how you play a
par it needs to play a part in the
international system and that needs to
be done in a way that embraces people
rather than divides them and the lesson
of the election the lesson of the voters
is that we failed to do that in 2010 and
in 2015 as this debate progresses what
is your personal role are you going to
stay on the sidelines in New York or do
you plan to return to Britain and put
your name forward as a possible leader
of the Labour Party I'm clearly not a
candidate
this leadership election I'm here in New
York and running a global charity that's
delivering aid to millions of people
around the world the commitment I have
to do job I've got doesn't change the
result of the election what I
passionately hope for is the friends and
colleagues who are in the UK now will
take up the mantle of a dynamic
progressive politics that's able to
speak to millions of people around the
country and maybe I'll be freer to
contribute to that debate because there
isn't going to be the soap opera
associated with my name and Ed's name
and I hope to be able to do so but
obviously I'm based here now and it's
going to be for leadership candidates to
put themselves forward in a way that
really does speak to the need to move
labour forward as well as move Britain
forward was that an uncomplicated
decision I know you spent the weekend
away in upstate New York a good time
place to think was that always going to
be your decision yes because I made a
commitment here that I'm only 18 months
into it's very very important that I
fulfill the commitments I've made here
the passion that I've got for Britain
and for labor is undimmed it's as strong
as ever a but it's clear that I'm not a
member of parliament I took that
decision not to be part of a soap opera
over the last five years I wanted labour
to be able to have that debate in a
clearer way make its case in a clear way
without any suggestion of distraction
from me and I hope now people can listen
to what I say as someone who's trying to
contribute but obviously isn't a party
to the race that's going on
